attributes.title: Focus On What You Do Best: Selling Toys
summary: Hasbro has reached a settlement with the New York Attorney General on potential child privacy violations, allowing it to concentrate on the coming holiday season.
Hasbro reported a first half, notable because it saw a rebound in its Girls’ segment and double-digit growth in markets that have weak economies.
As Hasbro re-positions its focus on what is good at, selling toys, we ask the question - is now the time to add Hasbro to your dividend portfolio.

attributes.content:
Analysis

Hasbro Reaches Settlement with New York Attorney General. Together with fellow toymaker Mattel (MAT) and media conglomerate Viacom (VIA), Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS) reached a settlement with the New York Attorney General to settle allegations that the companies used websites that allowed third-parties to track children's online activity in violation of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act.

The impact of the settlement on Hasbro is minimal - the three companies paid a total of $835 thousand, with Hasbro paying just $85,000 and this amount should have no material bearing on Hasbro's financial performance.

The more important consequence of the settlement is that it eliminates one distraction and enables Hasbro to focus on the forthcoming holiday season, with the company set to take advantage of the upcoming release of Star Wars: Rogue One with a new line of action figures. Hasbro's Rogue One offerings are expected to be among the 15 most sought-after toys this holiday season.

Investors looking to build a representative portfolio of stocks may wish to include Hasbro, one of the world's preeminent toy makers. In addition to licensing properties such as Star Wars, it also owns iconic gaming brands such as Magic: The Gathering and classic American toy brands such as My Little Pony, Play-Doh, and Nerf. This stable of brands and licensing partnerships enable Hasbro to have relatively stable revenues in an industry that is generally highly cyclical.

Hasbro has also paid a regular dividend since 1977 and has raised its dividend each year since 2010 and in twelve of the last thirteen years. At 2.62%, Hasbro's current dividend yield is above that of the average S&P500 company. Thus, investors who buy $10,000 worth of Hasbro's shares can expect to receive passive annual income of around $262 with some expectation that these payments will rise over time.
